	<item>
		<title>How Does Creativity Help?</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/01/how-does-creativity-help/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Jan 2009 16:36:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Micah</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=4</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Most people want to be innovative, unique, interesting (main-stream is so not cool). But, how can it be more than just a statement and actually help you?; help you succeed, help you communicate and help you stay fresh? Creativity has to have a purpose. There must be a concept, an end-goal that matters. Jonathan Ive said it so well when he defined design as a process of "stripping away" what is not needed, a simplifying of content and the display of information. It's not, then, so much about thinking up something cool as it is thinking of the best way to solve a problem to communicate a specific idea. Not to reveal a bias or anything, but someone asked Apple CEO Steve Jobs how they ended up creating the ipod as such a hip device. Jobs replied thatÂ  creating a cool device was never the intent, only something that would be simple and easy to use, and that's cool! Because there is so much "creativity" in culture today, stating the obvious is a refreshing alternative. So creatively simplify your content (whether written or visual). Your audience will thank you.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Broderson Awards Honor Design of Jetboil POP, Package and Catalog </title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2007/11/broderson-awards-honor-design-of-jetboil-pop-package-and-catalog/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Nov 2007 15:36:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=87</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-88" title="The Silver Broderson Award" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/05/broderson.png" alt="The Silver Broderson Award" width="210" height="285" />
<br />
Pica Design, a graphic design company located in Belfast, won the highest Award for the Integrated Marketing Campaign category at an awards ceremony Thursday evening, November 1st at the Marriott Sable Oaks in South Portland. The award was given to commend the design of the Jetboil POP, Package and Catalog, a series of designs highlighting Jetboilâs innovative engineering and cutting edge outdoor products. Pica Design was selected by Jetboil in 2005 to create and manage the rebranding of their award-winning line of outdoor gear.

The Broderson Awards honor creative excellence in Maine advertising and graphic design, and encourage higher creative standards. Judges are selected from around the U.S. and Canada by the Broderson Awards committee. For more information about the awards, please visit <a href="http://www.brodersons.com">www.brodersons.com</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Hydro-Photon, Inc., the makers of SteriPEN Handheld UV Water Purifiers presented &quot;2006 Vendor of the Year&quot; Award to Pica Design</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2006/11/hydro-photon-inc-the-makers-of-steripen-handheld-uv-water-purifiers-presented-2006-vendor-of-the-year-award-to-pica-design/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Nov 2006 18:32:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=96</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Upon arriving for an informal client meeting at our office at 111 Church Street in Belfast on Thursday, November 9th, Tim Wilson of Hydro-Photon, Inc. presented Rob Dietz with an engraved plaque. The plaque reads, "2006 Vendor of the Year Presented to Pica Design. In recognition of your professionalism, exceptional creativity, ability to graphically convey ideas, and grace under pressure. Thank you for making us look so good! From all of us at Hydro-Photon, Inc." This was a first-ever event in Pica Design history. We are honored to receive such praise, and we are committed to winning this award for years into the future.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Pica Helps to Bring The BoNE Show to Portland, Maine, Spring 2006</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2006/06/pica-helps-to-bring-the-bone-show-to-portland-maine-spring-2006/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 17 Jun 2006 09:12:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=98</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the first time in its 10-year history, AIGA Bostonâs BoNE (Best of New England) Design Show toured New England. Representing all six New England states, the bi-annual event recognized the best in successful visual communication in our region. The Portland installation of the BoNE Show was held at the Portland, Maine City Hall Rotunda for two weeks, June 5 â 16, with a closing reception on Thursday, June 15th. This was the first public event hosted by the newly formed Maine Chapter of the AIGA. For more information about the chapter, visit <a href="http://www.maine.aiga.org">http://www.maine.aiga.org</a> or <a href="http://www.boneshow.org">http://www.boneshow.org</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Rob Dietz of Pica Design Appointed to Board of AIGA Maine Chapter</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2006/01/rob-dietz-of-pica-design-appointed-to-board-of-aiga-maine-chapter-winter-2006/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Jan 2006 18:49:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=100</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[AIGA members living in Maine came together in the Fall of 2005 to petition the national organization to start a Maine Chapter. Rob Dietz was asked to participate on the board, as Communications Director. The first chapter events to take place were Monthly Movable Mixers (every third Thursday). These events are ongoing. Anyone who wants to learn more about AIGA Maine is invited. Mixers have been held at The Wine Bar, Domaine Gallery, Furniturea, The White Heart, and McCabe, Duval + Associates. For more information, visit <a href="http://www.maine.aiga.org">www.maine.aiga.org</a> or write to <a href="mailto:info@maine.aiga.org">info@maine.aiga.org</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New ClientâJetboil, Inc..âJoins Pica Roster</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2006/01/new-clientjetboil-incjoins-pica-roster-fall-2005/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 21 Jan 2006 15:51:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=102</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Jetboil, Inc., of Guild, New Hampshire, engaged Pica Design to design packaging for a holiday coffee bundle, the Jetboil Java Kit, in retail stores nationwide for the 2005 holiday season. We also worked with Jetboil to develop new packaging for their Group Cooking System, and a point of purchase endcap display for Jetboil product inventory. The Jetboil combines the power of a 21st century portable stove with the simplicity of a travel mug. Named âEditorâs Choiceâ for 2004 by Backpacker Magazine and âGear of the Yearâ by Outside Magazine, the product is available at more than 400 retailers nationwide. <a href="http://www.picadesign.com/portfolio.html?func=detail&amp;id=409">Click here to see examples of this work.</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>

We were contracted to complete both packaging solutions, one for the Firefly (the wide-mouth bottle lid-with-lamp that turns your water bottle into a lantern) and the Bottles (the first stainless steel wide-mouth bottles on the market).]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Web Tips &amp; Tricks</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2008/09/web-tips-tricks/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Sep 2008 17:24:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=120</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Browser Blunders</strong>
Have you ever seen a website and wondered why it looks soâ¦odd? If a site has not been tested and programmed to work with your Internet browser (and version), it can look positively wacky. We now test a siteâs functionality in various browsers, in various versions, including Mac and PC variations, before a site goes live.

<strong>D!d U Kn0w?</strong>
Creating a great password is your first line of defense against a hacker. Whatâs a great password? One with upper and lower case letters, a number or two, and maybe an exclamation point! Make a password tough to guess (but memorable for you), and youâll be one step closer to hacker-proof.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>120</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2008-09-24 10:24:51</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2008-09-24 17:24:51</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>web-tips-tricks</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech"><![CDATA[Tech]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Featured Project: Time for Belfast</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2008/07/featured-project-time-for-belfast/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Jul 2008 17:25:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=122</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-123" style="margin-right: 15px;" title="tfb-2" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/05/tfb-2.jpg" alt="tfb-2" width="300" height="150" />

Time for Belfast came to Pica Design to enhance their website. We re-organized the site, adding styles and structure, and posted new video clips for viewing. The mission of Time for Belfast is to put Belfast and its business community on the radar in Maine and beyond. The program is designed to confront strategic needs by giving students a voice and a leading role in a project that harnesses the converging medias of HD photography, Internet publication and TV airplay. To view their âspoof videoâ, click here. Time For Belfastâs website update project was spearheaded by our 2007-2008 intern, Zak Strassberg, under the direction of Web Designer Caitlin Holman.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>eNEWS for You!</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=255</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 May 2009 11:00:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=255</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We really do think email is one of the best ways to get the word out about your business. We're offering an eNEWS Starter Package for businesses who want to get the ball rolling.

<strong>Our eNEWS package cost is a one-time fee of $250 which includes</strong>
1) development of a re-usable eNEWS email template
2) email contact list set-up (re-usable, editable and expandable) - we can even add a form to your site so that you can collect customer emails directly!
3) eNEWS account set-up (a free, online account through which to manage your email campaigns)

<strong>Ongoing costs include</strong>
1) development of news content (writing, gathering images)
2) entering news content into eNEWS template
3) $10 plus 1 cent for every email contact (per eNEWS letter campaign, paid directly to eNEWS)
4) $5 browser testing (optional)
5) no annual or other fees

What's that you say? You already have an email marketing service? We've worked with most of the different companies out there, and we're always happy to help you improve the system you've got in place. We just want to make sure it's the best system for you - so check our chart below to compare services.
<table style="text-align: center;" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="500">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Service</strong></td>
<td><strong>Pica eNews</strong></td>
<td><strong>ConstantContact</strong></td>
<td><strong>MyEmma</strong></td>
<td><strong>MailChimp</strong></td>
<td><strong>iContact</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Monthly Cost</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>$15</td>
<td>$30</td>
<td>$10</td>
<td>$9.95</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Email list size</td>
<td>unlimited</td>
<td>0-500</td>
<td>0-1,000</td>
<td>0-500</td>
<td>0-250</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Sending Cost</td>
<td>$10</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Cost per Email</td>
<td>$0.01</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
<td>-</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
Most of the other services are built around monthly fees - which is great if you're sending emails that regularly. The trouble is that, like us, most small businesses are infrequent users, and end up spending large amounts of money for a monthly service they don't use enough. Thus, the Pica eNews service was born - allowing you to get out your news exactly when you want to, at a great price.

Questions? Comments? <a href="http://mailto:info@picadesign.com">Email us</a> or call 1-207-338-1740 to discuss!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>255</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-05-26 04:00:37</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-05-26 11:00:37</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[Design]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="marketing"><![CDATA[Marketing]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="social-networking"><![CDATA[Social Networking]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Pica eNEWS Service (email marketing)</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=310</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Cassidy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=310</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Our eNEWS Starter Package</strong> is a great way to open the door to online marketing.
<div>

<a onclick="javascript:pageTracker._trackPageview('/outbound/article/http://mailto:info@picadesign.com');" href="http://mailto:info@picadesign.com/"></a>The system we use is amazing: it helps us to keep track of multiple lists of subscribers, it can schedule sending the email at a specific timeâso you donât have to be awake to hit the âsendâ button, and itâll provide an interactive chart of who opened the email when and which links they clicked (yes, you do occasionally feel like a marketing spy).</div>
<div>Weâre definitely inspired to start communicating with our clients more through email, to share new site launches, logo designs, and all around good branding sense. Weâve also created a new email blast just for those of you interested in receiving special offers and marketing tips â if you want to be on that list <a href="http://picadesign.com/pica-points.html" target="_self">sign up here!</a> Inspired like we are, and want to start an eNews campaign of your own?</div>
<div>

<strong>
</strong><a onclick="javascript:pageTracker._trackPageview('/outbound/article/http://mailto:info@picadesign.com');" href="http://mailto:info@picadesign.com/"></a></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What has Pica been up to and where are they headed?</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=595</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=595</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm pretty sure that this question is NOT on the tip of your tongue but I'm here to give you an answer anyway, in part, because it's news but also because it is influencing the direction of Pica. As the slow economy has taken its toll and slowed up the project pipeline, we have decided to stay relevant by using our creativity and know-how to create a cause that we felt was important: TxtResponsibly.org.

TxtResponsiblly.org was created to raise awareness of the dangers of texting while driving and to prevent harmful injury or death caused by the act of texting recklessly.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What&#039;s in a Box?</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/05/whats-in-a-box/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 May 2009 20:24:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=136</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-137" style="margin-right: 15px;" title="Apple Boxes" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/05/macboxes.jpg" alt="Apple Boxes" width="301" height="450" />

We are unabashed fans of Apple. We love their computers, and we love their design. It's the best kind of inspiration; the kind we get to interact with every single day. As new people have joined the office, new computers have come on board as well. And you <em>know</em> we keep the packaging.

One day last week we were looking at the stack of Apple boxes, and realized that it tells the story of this whole company. And there, at the bottom, is the foundation of it all: the Power Mac G4 and Studio Display that Rob first worked on. It's a workhorse that is still part of the office!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Pica (by Any Other Name)</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/08/a-pica-by-any-other-name/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 06 Aug 2009 19:46:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=285</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[nggallery id=1]

All words have a meaning, but good ones come with more than one,
When we picked the Pica name we took on quite a sum.
The many things a Pica is may be more than you think
So we thought we'd share with you all these handy links

Pica means a <a title="Pica The Genus" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_%28genus%29" target="_blank">family of magpies</a>, and a <a title="Pica Press" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_Press" target="_blank">publisher of old </a>
<a title="Merille Grapes" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merille" target="_blank">Red-wine grapes</a> that wind and grow in the region of Garonne
There's a <a title="Pica, Chile" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica,_Chile" target="_blank">city found in Chile</a>, a <a title="Joe Pica" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Pica" target="_blank">pianist named Joe</a>,
and the <a title="Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Posterior_inferior_cerebellar_artery" target="_blank">pathway to your brain through which the blood does flow</a>
The <a title="Pica Eating Disorder" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_%28disorder%29" target="_blank">urge to eat things not quite food</a> goes by Pica too
But we hope you stick to food, good health it brings to you!

There are Institutes of Art in <a title="Portland Institute for Contemporary Art" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland_Institute_for_Contemporary_Art" target="_blank">Portland</a> and in <a title="Perth Institute of Contemporary Arts" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perth_Institute_of_Contemporary_Arts" target="_blank">Perth</a>
And the <a title="Phenolic Impregnated Carbon Ablator" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenolic_impregnated_carbon_ablator#PICA" target="_blank">heat shield on a spaceship so very far from Earth,</a>
If you should twist and turn the 'c' into a 'k'
And head into the mountains, way up above the fray
You may find a <a title="Pika" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pika" target="_blank">cousin to the rabbit, with ears just like a mouse
Who live in rocky hillsides, and whistle when they're roused</a>

But what <em>we</em> meant, in any case, <a title="Pica (unit of measurement)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_%28unit_of_measure%29" target="_blank">was the measurement of space</a>
Six picas in an inch to grant us design grace.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Curiously Strong and Undeniably Funny Advertising</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/06/curiously-strong-and-undeniably-funny-advertising/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Jun 2009 13:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=297</guid>
		<description></description>

	<item>
		<title>Something Funny in the State of Maine</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/06/something-funny-in-the-state-of-maine/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Jun 2009 14:18:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=313</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Within the last three weeks we've been noticing a show-stopping trend. We've found more than one local area site plagued by this notice:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-314" title="Suspected Malware Notice" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/20090611-q1pusdds8mqm8chddnqxuddikg.png" alt="Suspected Malware Notice" width="514" height="487" />

The problem is usually a piece of javascript that a hacker has added to the site. It can easily be removed as long as you can find the infected files and remove the necessary code. We're trying to figure out if this is a local occurence, or something that's more widespread. We'd love to hear from you if you have any idea as to the source of the attacks, or encounter other sites that have been attacked. And as always, keep your passwords tough to guess, and close to the chest!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>313</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-06-12 07:18:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-06-12 14:18:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>something-funny-in-the-state-of-maine</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="pica-service-announcement"><![CDATA[Pica Service Announcement]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech"><![CDATA[Tech]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="websites"><![CDATA[Websites]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>55</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Tim Shackelford]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>tim@5iveLeaf.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.5iveleaf.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>69.39.120.67</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-06-12 07:44:25</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-12 14:44:25</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I experienced 7 sites hacked with this same attack in the last couple of weeks. I believe I found the root.  A malware infected Windows PC that I wasn't even using for anything but streaming Hulu to a TV.  

This used to be a development computer so I had Dreamweaver on it and was using Dreamweaver to manage FTP connections to the sites I worked on.  Out of 9 FTP profiles in Dreamweaver, 7 were hacked, 1 did not have an index page, and 1 had switched hosting companies.  I'm still not certain how the malware got on that machine in the first place, but I have a feeling it probably occurred when visiting an infected site prior to the site being flagged and the warning being displayed.

The drastic but recommended solution, reformat the PC, clean the code from the website (I had great success by doing a site-wide find on the term "unescape"), then be sure to change the FTP password for the infected site.

Hope this helps!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>56</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Cait]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>caitlin@picadesign.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>204.181.131.70</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-12 20:36:47</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I'm so glad you were able to figure out the source and clear it up. We've seen the same issue on two other local sites that aren't ours, but are hosted locally. It would be interesting to know if the code on all is the same, and if they share hosting.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>

		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>57</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Justin]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>justin@justinrussell.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.justinrussell.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>69.131.106.112</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-06-13 09:20:46</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-13 16:20:46</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I've also found that sites that use older versions of software packages (WordPress, phpBB, etc.) tend to be very vulnerable to these kinds of attacks. It's important for someone - whether it's the site owner or a company that manages the site for a business - to keep that sort of software as up-to-date as possible!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>59</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Cait]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>caitlin@picadesign.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>204.181.131.70</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-06-15 07:21:59</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-15 14:21:59</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Absolutely. It's essential to keep up to date with the software packages - open source ones particularly. But at least one of the ones I've seen has been just html, and on a well protected local host.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>57</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>1</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>60</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Tim Shackelford]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>tim@5iveLeaf.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.5iveleaf.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>12.27.186.104</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-06-16 08:03:12</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-16 15:03:12</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Several of the sites that I dealt with recently were just plain HTML sites with no dynamic content and no CMS of any sort.  These were basic brochure sites.  

In this case it was just an infected PC running FTP software that was compromised.  This could even happen if a client using Contribute or similar site management software had their PC infected.  

I haven't heard yet if Macs have also been infected by this malware, but for now FTP info stored on my Mac seems to be safe despite sharing a network with the infected PC.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

	<item>
		<title>Pica Presents:</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/06/pica-presents/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Jun 2009 21:45:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=320</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-327" title="WebSmart_logo_RGB400px" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/WebSmart_logo_RGB400px.jpg" alt="WebSmart_logo_RGB400px" width="419" height="92" />
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">Join us for a nuts-and-bolts presentation on the benefits of websites for businesses. This is a great opportunity to ask questions about websites, network with other business owners and learn more about putting the Web to work for your business.</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica; font-weight: bold;">Event Details:</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">Thursday, June 25th</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">4:00 - 5:30 PM</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">Unity College Center for the Performing Arts</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">42 Depot Street, Unity, Maine</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica; min-height: 14.0px;"></p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica;">For registration and event information, call Julie Downer at UniTel: 948-3959;</p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica; color: #1750ae;"><span style="color: #000000;">or email <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="mailto:jdowner@uninets.net">jdowner@uninets.net</a></span></span></p>

<a href="mailto:jdowner@uninets.net"> </a>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica; color: #1750ae;"></p>
<p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Helvetica; color: #1750ae;"><span style="color: #000000;">Sponsored by Pica Design, LLC, UniTel and Unity College in Maine</span></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Gâ¢O Logic speaks up for stronger standards</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/06/g%e2%80%a2o-logic-speaks-up-for-stronger-standards/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Jun 2009 22:13:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=373</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Matt O'Malia, principal of Gâ¢O Logic, LLC, has a fantastic editorial on <a href="http://www.rollcall.com/">Roll Call</a> this week, in which he calls for a stronger energy standard in the upcoming American Clean Energy and Security Act.
<blockquote>âBuildings consume 40 percent of the energy produced in the United States, more energy than all of the cars on the roads today. And while automobile fuel efficiency is seriously debated as a path to save energy and money, building energy performance has not received as much scrutiny, even though we have the tools and technology to create super-efficient buildings today. A strong renewable electricity standard will mean these tools get used and these jobs created to make our buildings more efficient and begin to build the foundation of an American new energy economy.â

Read the whole editorial here: <a href="http://www.rollcall.com/news/36132-1.html" target="_blank">http://www.rollcall.com/news/36132-1.html</a></blockquote>
For more on Matt and Gâ¢O Logic's houses, check out their website at <a href="http://www.gologichomes.com" target="_blank">www.gologichomes.com</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>373</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>g%e2%80%a2o-logic-speaks-up-for-stronger-standards</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Google Voice</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/07/google-voice/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jul 2009 21:40:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=379</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hey, my name is Zak and I'm a summer intern here at Pica Design. While reading a blog today, I saw a rumor that Google Voice is supposedly opening to the public soon, and I decided to write this blog post to elucidate this great service for our readers. While many of you may not know what Google Voice is, I urge everyone with a Google Account (and who doesnât have one, these days) to pick up their own number.

Google Voice was originally called Grand Central, a company founded in 2005 which Google bought in 2007 for 97 million. Even years ago it was a promising business opportunity, and it remains a great service.

But what does Google Voice actually do? Well, itâs essentially a new phone number that allows a number of features that most phone services donât offer.

[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="457" caption="The Google Voice Inbox (Credit: Google)"]<img title="Google Voice Inbox" src="http://kimag.es/share/25945778.png" alt="The Google Voice Inbox (Credit: Google)" width="457" height="357" />[/caption]

First, it offers a unified number that youâll never lose when you move, get a new cell phone, or change phone service. This number can ring any other number of phones that you own, for example, when somebody calls my Google Voice number, both my cell phone and my home phone ring, which means I almost never miss a call.

Google Voice also features a robust voicemail system. When somebody leaves a voicemail on your Google Voice account, it notifies you via text message and even email, transcribing the voicemail into text and delivering it to your inbox.

Finally, there are a host of other featuresÂ  Google Voice offers. You can send and receive text messages for free online, screen calls, set different voicemail greetings to different contacts and groups, and more.

Google Voice is free, and a great service. I have been using it since 2008 and its unification makes life easier, which everybody deserves. I urge everyone to pick up a number and at least try it out.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>379</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-07-01 14:40:40</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-07-01 21:40:40</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>google-voice</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="event"><![CDATA[Event]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="social-networking"><![CDATA[Social Networking]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech"><![CDATA[Tech]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="websites"><![CDATA[Websites]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>

Here is a short clip from the question and answer session at our recent seminar at Unity Center for the Performing Arts.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Pica Design Accepts AIGA Challenge: The Conclusion</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/07/pica-design-accepts-aiga-challenge-the-conclusion/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2009 18:14:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=411</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A few weeks ago we shared our excitement about the letter 'O' and how we accepted the challenge to create the letter using found or re-purposed materials for the 2009 AIGA BoNE Show in Boston.Â Well, our efforts were well received and unique in that we submitted the only entry that used 100% organic materials. In this case, hay and twine. Ultimately, our 'O' was auctioned off to a bidder longing for Maine and now hangs proudly on a sun porch. Here are a handful of pictures of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/picadesign/sets/72157620858859900/" target="_blank">the project in the making</a> and the <a href="http://www.boneshow.org/photos/">final installation</a>. Thanks to all who participated. Enjoy!

[caption id="attachment_428" align="alignnone" width="335" caption="We Bring You the &#39;O&#39;"]<img class="size-full wp-image-428" title="3681077511_605d67441c" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/3681077511_605d67441c.jpg" alt="" width="335" height="500" />[/caption]

[caption id="attachment_414" align="alignnone" width="460" caption="Final Installation at Mass College of Art in Boston. Can you find our &#39;O&#39;?"]<img class="size-full wp-image-414    " title="BoneShow" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/BoneShow.jpg" alt="BoneShow" width="460" height="160" />[/caption] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>411</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Bits vs. Bytes</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/07/bits-vs-bytes/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jul 2009 13:49:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=447</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ever wonder exactly how fast your internet is? Why the 120 gigabyte hard drive you bought is only 111 gigabytes according to your computer? I've encountered a lot of confusion explaining these concepts to clients over the years. This mainly stems from the confusion about bits and bytes, two units that measure data. While many people use the two terms interchangeably, they are not the same thing.

[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption="Techy Russian Dolls (Image Credit: LaughingSquid.com)"]<img title="Credit: LaughingSquid.com" src="http://kimag.es/share/68566199.jpg" alt="Techy Russian Dolls" width="500" height="443" />[/caption]

<!--more-->

Computers use binary to compute and store data. The binary numeral system (base 2) consists of 1's and 0's which represent 'on' and 'off,' respectively, to the computer. A bit is a single binary digit, and therefore is read as either a 1 or and 0 by the computer. A byte is a collection of eight bits in modern computing systems, and therefore consists of a sequence of eight 1's or 0's.

For a (somewhat) practical example of how bits and bytes work, lets look at writing a sentence on your computer. The alphabet consists of 26 letters, each with an upper and lower case symbol, there are 10 numbers (0-9), and a wide variety of symbols, equaling a fair number of different characters that must be represented. Since a byte is 8 bits long, there are 255 different possibilities that a byte can represent (11111111 in binary is 255). This is the foundation for the ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) system, which assigns a different character for each possibility. The shortest complete sentence, "I am."converts to 0100100100100000011000010110110100101110 in binary, which is 40 bits or 5 bytes long. If you separate that string into sequences of 8 bits, you can see that 01001001 is âIâ, 00100000 is the space, 01100001 is the âaâ, etc. etc. This goes to show how bits and bytes are used to represent data on your computer, and how different the two terms are.

Anyways, it's when you get to the speed of your internet connection that bits vs. bytes becomes increasingly relevant. When you go to order high speed internet, you'll usually see Mbps after the connection speed. This stands for megabits per second, not megabytes per second like many think. A 1 Mbps (1,000,000 bits per second) connection is fast enough for most people, it allows a max download speed of about 125 kBps (kilobytes per second), but connections go as fast as 1 Gbps (gigabits per second [1,000,000,000 bits per second]) which allows a max download speed of 125 megabytes per second. People often write MBps when they mean Mbps, this is most likely a mistake. A 5MBps connection would be very expensive for anyone but a very large business.

As to why that new hard drive you bought isnât as big as you thought it would be, the discrepancy comes from the fact that hardware manufacturers cut corners when they do their calculations. Since binary uses just two different symbols, the way you count is different from that in base ten. 1 in binary is 1 in base ten, 10 in binary is 2 in base ten, 100 is 4, 1000 is 8, and so on and so forth. It advances in powers of two, This means that it takes 1024 bytes to make a kilobyte, 1024 kilobytes to make a megabyte, and 1024 megabytes to make a gigabyte. The people who make hard drives cheat and assume that 1000 bytes is a kilobyte, 1000 kilobytes is a megabyte, and 1000 megabytes is a gigabyte and say itâs close enough that it doesnât matter. They say that a hard drive which holds 120,000,000,000 bytes holds 120 gigabytes, while in actuality it only holds 111 gigabytes (120,000,000,000 Ã· 1024 Ã· 1024 Ã· 1024). This is why you never get as many gigabytes as you think you do.

Even people in the tech world have trouble with this concept of bits vs. bytes at times, but hopefully now you won't. While this subject may not seem terribly important, it's very relevant to computing in general and is a good bit of trivia. I hope that this post hasn't bored you too much, and that you walk away knowing something new.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>447</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-07-16 06:49:29</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-07-16 13:49:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>bits-vs-bytes</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech"><![CDATA[Tech]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Please put me back on hold.</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/07/please-put-me-back-on-hold/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Jul 2009 20:05:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Cassidy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=457</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_459" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Timm Schamberger / DDP"]<img class="size-full wp-image-459" title="brubeck300" src="http://www.picadesign.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/brubeck300.jpg" alt="Timm Schamberger / DDP" width="300" height="225" />[/caption]

We regularly get people asking us what our hold music is. It isn't often that people like to be on hold. Since we added Dave Brubeck's Take Five as our hold music, people have regularly commented on it. Sometimes even asking to be put back on hold so they could hear the rest of the song. The following is a short story on Brubeck's Take Five album that appeared on NPR.

Dave Brubeck: An Unlikely Hit, 50 Years Strong

All Things Considered, June 12, 2009 - In 1959, jazz pianist Dave Brubeck topped the pop charts and shook up the notion of rhythm in jazz with an odd-metered song called "Take Five."
Only trained musicians might understand exactly what gave the Paul Desmond-penned song its flow. It was all in the time signature: five beats to the measure, a departure from more traditional four-four time in jazz. It was cutting-edge and cool â a song millions would scoop up and savor. In an interview with Michele Norris, Brubeck explains what made the time signature so difficult.

"You were brought up playing in four-four," Brubeck says. "Everybody could walk to it and dance to it. Put an extra beat on it â everybody's tripping."

Fifty years ago, "Take Five" appeared on Time Out, a title that served as a double-entendre. Those in the know knew it referenced the mood and the music's meter.

At age 89, Brubeck has slowed down, but he's still playing and writing music.

"The more you get to play, the better it is â just play as you can while you can," Brubeck says. "I can't wait for the next job so we can play."]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>457</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-07-20 13:05:43</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-07-20 20:05:43</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>please-put-me-back-on-hold</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	<item>
		<title>I like to Ride My Tricycle, Tricycle, Tricycle.</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/07/i-like-to-ride-my-tricycle-tricycle-tricycle/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Jul 2009 14:50:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Cassidy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=529</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_536" align="aligncenter" width="471" caption="Micah Ellis"]<a href="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/DSC_76672.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-536" title="DSC_7667" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/DSC_76672.jpg" alt="Micah Ellis" width="471" height="702" /></a>[/caption]

For the past few years I have had the benefit of witnessing countless children enjoying the winged tricycle out my office window. Every summer the hordes of tourists descend on Belfast, Maine. Every child that sees this tricycle has to sit on it and ring the bell. Usually this is a 10-15 minute event. I hear the wonderful sounds of laughter and screaming children as they take turns trying to push the pedals and make those wings go up and down, up and down. I can think of nothing better to brighten up a rainy summer than happy children.

But on this particular day I looked out my window only to see a co-worker screaming with delight. In this instance a picture really is worth a thousand words.

Don't forget to stop in Belfast on your way up the Maine coast and check out all the bike installations throughout town.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Perspective</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/08/perspective/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Aug 2009 16:15:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The concept of perspective is important in art and design. It can refer to how objects appear to the eye or to a way to make realistic art. However, it can also mean one's point of view, their position in the sense of '<em>everything</em>'. I could talk about how we are one of billions, how nature dwarfs us until we are like a grain of sand in a limitless beach, but this would be depressing. I prefer to think about it the other way around: we are something special in a majestic universe. When I saw this video, I didn't quake at the implications that we are nothing, instead I marveled at the scale of our cosmos. All I see is limitless potential.

httpvhd://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oAVjF_7ensg]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>553</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-08-12 16:15:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>perspective</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="perspective"><![CDATA[perspective]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="philosophy"><![CDATA[philosophy]]></category>

	<item>
		<title>Dimensions</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/08/dimensions/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 21:59:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=561</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It's me again, bringing yet another taste of the esoteric, cool, but ultimately useless once again. Today I found a video explaining the dimensions from 0-10, and I thought I'd share it. Once again, it's a bit of perspective. Chicken Soup for the Three Dimensional Soul?

<script src="http://flash.revver.com/player/1.0/player.js?mediaId:99898;width:480;height:392" type="text/javascript"></script>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>561</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-08-19 14:59:18</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-08-19 21:59:18</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>dimensions</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="dimensions"><![CDATA[dimensions]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="fun"><![CDATA[Fun]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="perspective"><![CDATA[perspective]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="string-theory"><![CDATA[string theory]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="video"><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Spreading Peace for the Holidays... How Sweet it is.</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/12/spreading-peace-for-the-holidays-how-sweet-it-is/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 17:51:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=620</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What a better way to celebrate the holidays than to help spread peace through Blueberry and Strawberry Preserves. Peace Preserves, a Client of Pica Design, is a local business that wasÂ created to provide an array of unique fundraising items to nonprofit organizations and the retail market. Products were developed as a vehicle to express the simple message to "Spread Peace, Peace Works". When you buy their products, you send funds directly to youth organizations who are working towards achieving peace in our world today. To learn more on Pica Design's involvement in helping Peace Preserves to develop their brand identity and packaging, <a href="http://www.picadesign.com/index.php?option=com_joomgallery&amp;func=detail&amp;id=490&amp;Itemid=40" target="_self">click here</a>. To purchase Peace Preserves for gifts or for your holiday enjoyment, you can visit a variety of local establishments such as the <a href="http://www.farmersfare.com/" target="_blank">Farmers Fare</a>, the <a href="http://belfast.coop/" target="_blank">Belfast Co-op</a>, <a href="http://www.wholefoodsmarket.com/stores/portland-me/" target="_blank">Whole Foods in Portland</a> or directly through the <a href="http://www.peacepreserves.com/" target="_blank">Peace Preserves</a> website . Enjoy!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Grammar, Shmammar?</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2009/02/grammar-shmammar/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Feb 2009 20:57:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.picadesign.com/blog/?p=49</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!--StartFragment-->
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>Here is a teeny tiny grammatical matter having to do with the apostrophe and its common misuse when it comes to <em><strong>itâs</strong></em></span><span> and <em><strong>its</strong></em></span><span>. Does this ever confuse you?</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span><em><strong>Itâs</strong></em></span><span> is hiding a letter. That's because <em><strong>it's</strong></em></span><span> is a contraction. It's made up of two words:<em> <strong>it</strong></em></span><span> and <em><strong>is</strong></em></span><span>. So, if you want to say, âIt is important,â you can also say, â<em><strong>Itâs</strong></em></span><span> important.â</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>A tiny matter, butÂ <em>itâs</em></span><span> important, nonetheless.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span><span>And hereâs more: <em><strong>itâs</strong></em></span><span> is not the same as<em> <strong>its</strong></em></span><span>.Â <span>If you want to say <em><strong>its</strong></em></span><span> importance is irrelevant to you, you donât need the apostrophe.</span></span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>Let's review:</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>â¢ use an apostrophe when you want to say, "It is."</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>â¢ do not use an apostrophe with a possessive pronoun: hers, his, or its</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span>So, say what you want to say, and mean what you want to mean.Â <span>You donât want to say, âIts cloudy today." Even if it is.</span>Â Â </span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>49</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-02-19 13:57:24</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-02-19 20:57:24</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>grammar-shmammar</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aktt_hash_meta</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_comments_status</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{i:14;s:1:"1";}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>14</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Brian DeKoning]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>bekoning@vtldesign.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.vtldesign.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>65.175.214.24</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_approved>post-trashed</wp:comment_approved>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Who Needs a Designer when you have Wordpress Themes?</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/03/who-needs-a-designer-when-you-have-wordpress-themes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 31 Mar 2010 15:21:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Cassidy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=664</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I often wonder what the future of Web Design will be. Is the information superhighway going to become an infrastructure just like our roadways and city's are designed. A place where every page has the same navigation structure and always leads to the same intersection. In theory it would be great if say for instance every state run organization shared the same navigational structure. This way we could all find the information easier without having to learn how to navigate each site. On the other hand it wouldn't be great if every tattoo shop had the same look and structure. They would then lack the originality and character that attracts people to certain shops.

Wordpress themes and others like it are changing the way the landscape looks and creating an economical option for small companies. The benefit is that it gives start-up companies an option to get online without breaking the budget. The risk is that your business might not stand out from the rest.

I am not sure what the future holds for web design but I am sure that Wordpress themes will be around for a while. Please choose wisely.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>664</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-03-31 08:21:06</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-03-31 15:21:06</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>who-needs-a-designer-when-you-have-wordpress-themes</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="company-news"><![CDATA[Company News]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[Design]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="web-design-of-the-future"><![CDATA[web design of the future]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="wordpress-themes"><![CDATA[Wordpress themes]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>aktt_notify_twitter</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aktt_hash_meta</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[9]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>221</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Brian DeKoning]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>bdekoning@vtldesign.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.nhsocialmedia.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>72.71.200.3</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-03-31 08:45:04</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-03-31 15:45:04</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I've been considering the same questions lately. WordPress themes available for free or under $50 have really democratized web design. But it also seems to be giving a lot of designers exposure they wouldn't have otherwise. I think the need for custom design will always be there, but it is interesting to see that people with no web dev experience can set up a decent WordPress site in a day. Another thing to consider is how easy WordPress makes it for clients to manage their sites. We just launched the SENH Habitat site with a lot of WordPress action to make it easy for them to do so.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>222</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[James Mehorter]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>james@picadesign.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.7mdesign.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>216.195.184.219</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-04-13 07:14:25</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-04-13 14:14:25</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hey Brian,

I totally agree! On one hand we are very happy that individuals without capitol can create a nice web presence. It is quite common now for people to make their own sites with tools like Apple's iWeb, GoDaddy's WebsiteTonight, RapidWeaver, and even Wordpress Themes. However, we have many clients come to us after they've been sold on these products only to find they hate their template site and find they can't do some important things like SEO. Not to mention the massive confusion they experience with hosting and domain problems. They end up hiring us, wishing they had come to us in the first place. We feel a middle-road is the best solution; having a customized Wordpress theme created to match your branding, and letting a Web Development company handle all the tech / hosting intricacies. And yes, you are very correct - the Wordpress Admin is by-far the most user/client-friendly Content Management System out there! 

You can't buy a build-your-own-car or house kit and expect to have it come out square and level unless you're a carpenter. 

James]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>9</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>New SteriPEN Retail Packaging</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/05/new-steripen-retail-packaging/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 11 May 2010 15:23:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Cassidy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=715</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Pica Design was asked to create New Packaging for a company in Blue HIll, Maine called Hydro-Photon. Hydro-Photon sells a product called the SteriPEN. Pica Design has been designing all of the SteriPEN collateral for the last 5 years. They recently released 3 new SteriPEN products; The SteriPEN Emergency, Mini, and Traveler. Each product is intended for a different market but they wanted the packages to have a similar look and feel. <a href="http://www.picadesign.com/index.php?option=com_joomgallery&amp;func=detail&amp;id=613&amp;Itemid=40">Click Here for a larger view.</a>

[caption id="attachment_716" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="SteriPEN Emergency, Mini, Traveler"]<a href="http://www.picadesign.com/index.php?option=com_joomgallery&amp;func=detail&amp;id=613&amp;Itemid=40"><img class="size-medium wp-image-716" title="3Packages72dpi" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/3Packages72dpi-300x123.jpg" alt="SteriPEN Emergency, Mini, Traveler" width="300" height="123" /></a>[/caption] ]]></content:encoded>

		<title>New Concert Poster for Belfast Maskers</title>

		<title>New Poster for Vision Source</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/05/new-poster-for-vision-source/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 May 2010 14:41:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Micah</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=736</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We recently finished designing a poster for Vision Source, a Belfast optometrist practice for Dr. Jeffery Dutch, OD and Dr. Amy Marnecheck, OD. The poster will be used for Vision Source's annual Trunk Show, a special sale of high-end eyewear brands, on Thursday, May 28th. The posters measure 3ft. by 3ft. and were printed by Warner Graphics in Camden.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-739" title="10-115_2010TrunkShow_FNL" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/10-115_2010TrunkShow_FNL1.jpg" alt="10-115_2010TrunkShow_FNL" width="475" height="475" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Pica Design Awarded DLLT Contract</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/07/pica-design-awarded-dllt-contract/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Jul 2010 03:18:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=762</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We'd like to welcome Downeast Lakes Land Trust as a new Client. In early June 2010, Pica Design was awarded a contract from <a href="http://www.downeastlakes.org/" target="_blank">Downeast Lakes Land Trust</a> (DLLT) for the design and development of their new website. DLLT is a community-based 501(c)(3) non-profit founded in 2001 in Grand Lake Stream, Maine. Their mission is to contribute to the long-term economic and environmental well-being of the Downeast Lakes region through the conservation and exemplary management of its forests and waters. To learn more about their initiatives and the land that they are conserving, visit: <a href="http://www.downeastlakes.org/" target="_blank">http://www.downeastlakes.org</a>

To learn more about Pica Design's partnership benefits with other non-profits like Downeast Lakes Land Trust, contact us today at: <a href="mailto:info@picadesign.com">info@picadesign.com</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Pica Design Launches WCGH.org Website</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/08/pica-design-launches-wcgh-website/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Aug 2010 18:57:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Rob</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=776</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Pica Design is pleased to announce the new redesign of Waldo County General Hospital's website at <a href="http://www.wcgh.org/" target="_blank">www.wcgh.org</a>! Waldo County Healthcare, Inc. (WCHI) serves the healthcare needs of Waldo County residents through Waldo County General Hospital, five rural health centers, home health and hospice services, public health nursing, physiciansâ offices and educational programs.<p>&nbsp;</p>
<div><a href="http://www.wcgh.org" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-788" title="Waldo County General Hospital Home Page" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/10-08-04-151158-Waldo-County-General-Hospital-1024x624.jpg" alt="Waldo County General Hospital Home Page" width="430" height="262" /></a></div><p>&nbsp;</p>
Waldo County General Hospital (WCGH) is a not-for-profit community hospital committed to providing excellent care for patients and their families in a friendly, caring atmosphere in line with its mission to be the BEST. Services are provided as efficiently as possible with an eye on the future and in collaboration with other community-minded agencies. All services are provided regardless of ability to pay in accordance with the hospitalâs financial assistance policy.<p>&nbsp;</p>
In early March, Pica Design was selected to redesign and redevelop the hospital's new website working within the brand standards outlined by MaineHealth. The goal of the new website design was to remain accessible and intuitive to a broad-range audience while incorporating the newest tools and technologies to allow the hospital to enhance their existing communications and open new channels of communication. In addition, the new website needed to offer the ability to allow Hospital staff to manage every aspect of the website. Over the past six months, we have worked closely with the Hospital's administrative staff to implement and test all of the site's new functionality, including:

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.wcgh.org/" target="_blank">a search-as-you-type feature to help people locate Doctor specialties that are difficult to spell</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.wcgh.org/site-tools/accessibility/" target="_blank">built-in web accessibility tools for the handicapped (for example, the site can be navigated without a mouse)</a></li>
	<li>a find-a-doctor feature for specific medical needs</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.wcgh.org/news/" target="_blank">news features &amp; resources: subscribe to RSS news feeds, newsletters (InPulse &amp; Journey to Health), and the news blog</a></li>
</ul>

One of the bigger challenges for our team was to code the new website to work on every browser and keep the website as accessible as possible. Should a website break occur, the user has the ability to 'Submit a Website Problem' through a link located within the footer navigation.<p>&nbsp;</p>
In addition to developing the new website, Pica Design is providing hosting services as well as consulting on web and social media strategies to help the Hospital get the most out of its online presence. To learn more about Pica website development and social media strategies, contact us by phone at 207-338-1740 or email at: info@picadesign.com]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Pica Design Launches Waldo Community Action Partners (WCAP) Website</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/10/pica-design-launches-waldo-community-action-partners-wcap-website/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Oct 2010 20:34:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=843</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Waldo Community Action Partners (WCAP) has a new website--a dynamic, information-rich site that will be updated and maintained by WCAP staff.

Waldo Community Action Partners' mission is âto create opportunities for people to improve their quality of life.â They aim to make a big impact on Waldo County citizens by expanding opportunities for health, comfort, and financial and personal development. The site provides information and contacts for public transportation, education programs, energy services, emergency resources, health programs and community projects.

Using revolutionary web techniques, Pica Design programmed the site so that users with disabilities can navigate it without the use of a mouse. Site visitors can also follow quicklinks and visual icons to intuitively locate the content they need. We consulted WAI* and Section 508** to understand the needs of the disability community, then created solutions that we implemented across the site. The site also includes a private website for the WCAP staff to communicate and share documents between departments.

To check out the website or to learn more about how Waldo Community Action Partners supports our community everyday, click here: <a href="http://www.waldocap.org/">http://www.waldocap.org</a>

* Pica Design developed navigation for the site to be WAI Compliant for Accessibility. WAI stands for Web Accessibility Initiative and their mission is to work with organizations around the world to develop strategies, guidelines and resources to help make the Web accessible to people with disabilities (for more information, visit www.w3.org/WAI/).
** â508 Compliantâ refers to respect for and adherence to Section 508, which requires that Federal agenciesâ electronic and information technology is accessible to people with disabilities.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>843</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-10-20 13:34:21</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-10-20 20:34:21</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>pica-design-launches-waldo-community-action-partners-wcap-website</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="company-news"><![CDATA[Company News]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[Design]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="websites"><![CDATA[Websites]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Land Trust&#039;s Conservation + Recreation Site Goes Live</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/10/land-trusts-conservation-recreation-site-goes-live/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Oct 2010 19:17:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=852</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Downeast Lakes Land Trust (DLLT) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization founded in 2001 by local residents of Grand Lake Stream, Maine. They contribute to the long-term economic and environmental well-being of the Downeast Lakes region through the conservation and exemplary management of its forests and waters.
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top">Pica Design answered a request for proposal from DLLT in April of 2010 and was chosen to redesign the organization's outmoded web site. We reorganized content and designed a website which would be a resource for visitors, both for conservation news and as a guide to recreation opportunities in the region. A home-page slideshow features photos that capture the beauty and wildlife of the Grand Lake Stream area. We also built in new functionality: a blog, event calendar, and social networking tools. The site is optimized for search engines and traffic analysis. And--last, but not least--what would a non-profit be without its supporters? The new website allows visitors to contribute online; donors can direct a donation to a specific project, or donate in the name of someone special. 

We are excited to see how the site performs, so we'll be checking in through Google Analytics and Google Webmaster Tools. In six months, we will analyze the site's performance in search engines, part of our effort to optimize DLLT's online visibility and help DLLT staff and volunteers do what they do best: Conserving Forests and Lakes - For People - Forever.
</td>
<td valign="top">
[caption id="attachment_860" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Downeast Lakes Land Trust Website: BEFORE"]<a href="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DLLT-Before1.png" target="_blank"><img style="border: 0px initial initial;" title="&lt;strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;DowneastLakes.Org BEFORE&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DLLT-Before1-300x273.png" alt="" width="300" height="176" /></a>[/caption]
[caption id="attachment_875" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Downeast Lakes Land Trust Website: AFTER"]<a href="https://www.downeastlakes.org" target="_blank"><img class="size-medium wp-image-875  " style="border: 0px initial initial;" title="Picture4Crop" src="http://blog.picadesign.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Picture4Crop2-300x176.png" alt="" width="300" height="176" /></a>[/caption]
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<br />
Check out the new site @ <a href="https://www.downeastlakes.org">https://www.downeastlakes.org</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>852</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-10-25 12:17:07</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>A Great Ad Starts With</title>
		<link>http://blog.picadesign.com/2010/12/a-great-ad-starts-with/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 08 Dec 2010 21:22:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.picadesign.com/?p=910</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>What makes a great ad?</strong> We just raised this question at Pica Design when brainstorming new advertising ideas for VillageSoup. We decided to compile our thoughts and share them here on our blog. As you will see, our responses were varied, but they also overlap. A common thread is the understanding that great advertising grabs our attention, and we know a good ad when we see one. We invite you to delve into our responses and share your own thoughts by posting a 'Reply' under the blog.

+ a connection to the audience. If an ad connects with me--through humor or imagery or an element of surprise--it will be memorable. I'll look up a website to learn more.

+ a concise message delivered in a bold and different way.

+ making the most ofÂ beauty. Beauty is inspiring and it's memorable. If an ad inspires you, you remember it.

+ a great company, product or service. Then, it's about clear communication and spot-on execution. So, it's a great idea + useful design; that's what makes a great ad.

+ authenticity,Â creativity, ingenuity and uniqueness.

+ few words. It makes the essential points and directs us to learn more.

+ a great marketing plan.

+ a great visual. I think one great visual is better than three not-so-great ones. Great advertising isÂ simple and uncluttered.

+ knowing the difference between advertising and marketing.

+ standing out in a crowd.

+ immediacy.Â When an ad incorporates an offer to take advantage of right now, I pay attention.

<span style="font-size: 18px;"><strong>How would you finish the statement,</strong> <strong>'A great ad starts with...' ?</strong></span>

<!-- p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 14.0px Helvetica} span.s1 {text-decoration: underline ; color: #0050b0} -->Need to jumpstart your marketing plans for 2011? Update your website? Develop a company logo? Redefine your brand? We offer a FREE one hour consultation at our design studio in Belfast. Call us today at (207) 338-1740 or email us at <a href="mailto:info@picadesign.com">info@picadesign.com</a> to schedule your meeting with our creative team.

<a href="http://www.picadesign.com" target="_blank">www.picadesign.com</a>]]></content:encoded>
